results.title: Hustlers
results.brief_description: A crew of savvy former strip club employees band together to turn the tables on their Wall Street clients.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Ladies who own the narrative
constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

constellations_other.name: Aquaman VFX
constellations_other.description: As well as becoming a global box-office sensation, Aquaman (2018) featured groundbreaking visual effects from Australian companies such as Method Studios.

results.description: A crew of savvy former strip club employees band together to turn the tables on their Wall Street clients.

results.title: Hustler white (E)
results.creator_credit: Rick Castro, Bruce LaBruce, Jurgen Bruning and Hustler White productions
results.brief_description: Co-director and star Bruce LaBruce’s sleazy and explicit tour of the LA hustler and porn scene is a humorous and twisted take on Billy Wilder’s “Sunset Boulevard and” the more unsavory moments of “Whatever happened to Baby Jane”. Model Tony Ward stars as Monti- a hustler who becomes the lust object and obsession for Bruce Labruce’s melodramatic journalist, Jurgen Anger. “Hustler White“‘s use of real life hustlers and gay porn actors, along with Labruce’s own gay porn background (he has directed and stared in the underground and very pornographic, Super 8 1/2 and No Skin off my Arse) gives the film a candid documentary feel. Hustler White was co-directed by gay photographer Rick Castro.

results.title: Hush little baby (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
Family life in 18th century America is pictured with authenticity and charm in this enchanting animated rendition of the traditional folk lullaby. Illustrated and based on the book by Aliki.

results.title: Hush hush, sweet Charlotte
results.creator_credit: Robert Aldrich, Associates and Aldrich Company and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Bette Davis plays Charlotte Hollis, a reclusive spinster still mourning the savage murder of the man she loved 37 years ago. When the state wants Charlotte’s grand property to construct a new highway, she turns to her cousin Miriam (Olivia de Havilland) and an old friend, Drew (Joseph Cotton) to help her resist. What follows is a series of chilling scares and shocks. Also stars Agnes Moorehead.

results.title: Hush [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Katherine Fry and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Beginning and concluding at an airport, “Hush” is about a family living in a caravan park who are estranged from one another by a secret, unspoken crime that involves one of the sisters. Cast includes Hayley O’Donnell, Marieke Hardy, Saskia Post and Greg Carroll.

results.title: Hush-a-bye baby
results.creator_credit: Margo Harkin, Tom Collins, British Screen Finance, Channel 4 and Derry Film and Video Workshop
results.brief_description: Set in the Catholic community in Derry, Ireland, at the time of the ‘supergrass’ trials in the wake of the abortion referendum in the Republic, this is the story of four teenage girls: Goretti (Emer McCourt); Sinead (Sinead O’Connor); Dinky (Cathy Casey) and Majella (Julie Rodgers). In particular it revolves around their attempts to come to grips with their sexuality in a confusing and oppressive culture. Things come to a head when Goretti becomes pregnant by her boyfriend Ciarin (Michael Liebman), who, meanwhile has been lifted in an army swoop. This is a tough yet wholly sympathetic view of a working class community, a view which whilst touchingly communicating the vulnerability of young people exploring their sexuality, never romanticises the attitudes of its characters toward each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margo Harkin, Tom Collins, British Screen Finance, Channel 4 and Derry Film and Video Workshop

results.title: Husbands and wives
results.creator_credit: Woody Allen, Robert Greenhut and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: A long-time married couple played by Judy Davis and Sydney Pollack astound their friends (Woody Allen and Mia Farrow), by announcing their separation. The film gained notoriety not so much for itself, but because it was the last film that Allen and Farrow made before their own much publicised breakup. Allen uses handheld camera techniques which gives the film a documentary type feel. Judy Davis was nominated for an Academy Award for her performance and Woody Allen for the screenplay. Co-starring Juliette Lewis, Liam Neeson, Blythe Danner, Nora Ephron and Lysette Anthony.

results.title: Hurt
results.brief_description: ‘Hurt’ is an extraordinary project in which film and video cameras were put in the hands of 250 under-privileged young people from rural regions of northern New South Wales and Western Victoria. The basic materials derived from this process comprised hundreds of poignant, beautiful, cruel and comforting stories. Filmmakers Phillip Crawford and Matthew Priestly from youth arts organization BIG hART worked with the young people to create an AFI award winning film, ‘Hurt’ in which fragmented, poetic and haunting stories of isolation and hardship are told through the words and images created by the young artists. In this new ACMI commissioned project filmmakers from BIG hART have turned the material into a multi-screen spatial installation that puts the viewer into the midst of this fragmented world of broken lives, beauty and bravery.

results.title: Hurt
results.creator_credit: Mathew Perry, Phillip Crawford, The Omni Group, BIG hART and Arts Northwest
results.brief_description: Initiated by BIG hART, a non profit organisation which pilots art projects for marginalised young people, this film allowed rural Australian youth to translate stories based on their personal experiences of familial violence onto film. Made as part of a violence prevention strategy funded by the New South Wales government it was shot on location in several central New South Wales towns where young people participated in workshops to develop narrative material for the project. As well as shaping narratives, they operated film equipment, art directed and acted in the film. While it is based on real events, the film is not a documentary, but a creative dramatisation which employs innovative editing and visual effects to convey the participants painful feelings and experiences of domestic violence and social dislocation.
